message.content: We refer to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) guidelines for vaccinations during pregnancy. The recommended vaccination at week 30 of gestation is the Tdap vaccine, which protects against tetanus, diphtheria, and pertussis. The live attenuated influenza vaccine is not recommended during pregnancy, and varicella and herpes zoster vaccines are not routinely given during pregnancy.

We refer to official recommendations from the CDC for help. The recommended vaccination for pregnant women at week 30 of gestation is the Tdap vaccine, to protect against tetanus, diphtheria, and pertussis. The other options are contraindicated in pregnancy or not recommended at this time.

We refer to CDC guidelines on vaccination during pregnancy for help. The recommended vaccination for pregnant women at week 30 of gestation is the Tetanus, diphtheria, and acellular pertussis (Tdap) vaccine to protect both the mother and the baby from pertussis. Live attenuated influenza vaccine is not recommended during pregnancy, Varicella vaccine is recommended for women who are not immune to chickenpox before pregnancy, and herpes zoster vaccine is not recommended during pregnancy.

We refer to CDC guidelines for vaccination during pregnancy. The Tdap vaccine is recommended during every pregnancy, preferably between weeks 27 and 36, to protect the mother and the newborn from pertussis (whooping cough) infection. Live attenuated vaccines, such as the influenza and varicella vaccines, are contraindicated during pregnancy. The herpes zoster vaccine is not recommended during pregnancy as it is a live vaccine.

We refer to Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) guidelines for help. According to CDC, pregnant women should receive the Tdap vaccine during each pregnancy to provide protection against pertussis to the newborn. Live attenuated influenza vaccine is not recommended for pregnant women, while varicella and herpes zoster vaccines are not recommended during pregnancy.

We refer to the CDC guidelines on vaccination during pregnancy for help. Tdap vaccine is recommended during each pregnancy, preferably between weeks 27 and 36, to protect the mother and the newborn from pertussis. Live attenuated influenza vaccine is not recommended during pregnancy. Varicella and herpes zoster vaccines are contraindicated during pregnancy.

We refer to Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) guidelines for vaccination during pregnancy. The recommended vaccination for this patient at week 30 of gestation is Tetanus, diphtheria, and acellular pertussis (Tdap), which is given to protect the newborn from pertussis (whooping cough). The other options are not recommended during pregnancy. Live attenuated influenza vaccine and varicella vaccine are contraindicated in pregnancy, and herpes zoster vaccine is not indicated during pregnancy.

We refer to CDC guidelines for help. The recommended vaccination for pregnant women at 27-36 weeks of gestation is the Tdap vaccine to protect against tetanus, diphtheria, and pertussis. This vaccine can provide passive immunity to the baby against pertussis. Live vaccines, such as the influenza and varicella vaccines, are generally not recommended during pregnancy. The herpes zoster vaccine is only recommended for individuals aged 50 years or older.

We refer to CDC guidelines on vaccination during pregnancy for help. The recommended vaccine for a pregnant woman at 27-36 weeks of gestation is Tdap to protect against pertussis. The influenza vaccine should also be administered annually, but it is not a live attenuated vaccine. Varicella and herpes zoster vaccines are contraindicated during pregnancy.

We refer to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) guidelines on vaccine recommendations during pregnancy. The recommended vaccine for pregnant women at week 30 of gestation is the Tdap vaccine to protect against tetanus, diphtheria, and pertussis. Live attenuated vaccines, such as influenza and varicella, are not recommended during pregnancy due to theoretical risks to the fetus. The herpes zoster vaccine is only recommended for individuals over the age of 50, and is not routinely recommended for pregnant women.
